item.content:encoded:
Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643)

Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary who marked the transition from Renaissance to Baroque music.

Until the age of forty, Monteverdi worked primarily on madrigals, composing a total of nine books. In about four years, Monteverdi completed his first book of twenty-one madrigals for five voices. Overall, the first eight madrigals show the massive development from Renaissance polyphonic to baroque monodic styles.

He wrote L’Orfeo, one of the earliest operas in the history of music, an innovative work that remains a part of today’s orchestra’s repertoire. Additionally, he has written sacred music.

Orlando di Lasso (1532 – 1594)

Lasso was a Franco-Flemish composer. With more than two thousand compositions to his credit, he was a prolific and versatile author. This collection includes all genres of his day, secular and sacred, including the mass, secular chanson in several languages, Latin motets, hymns, and madrigals. When he held the position of Kapellmeister at the Munich court, at the end of his life, he cultivated sacred music with a special dedication.

He is considered the chief representative of the mature polyphonic style of the Netherlands school, along with Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina. At the end of the 16th century, he was one of the most famous and influential musicians in Europe.

Regarding his madrigals, which he penned while living in Rome, his style was clear and concise, and his tunes were memorable.

Comparison between Orlando di Lasso’s Matona, mia cara and Claudio Monteverdi’s Ah, Dolente Partita

The main reason I chose to compare these two madrigals is their contrasting themes. Lasso’s one is a jovial, lighthearted, and almost mocking monologue between a German soldier and a supposedly Italian woman. Contrary to Monteverdi, his lament is a sombre recognition of death in late life.

From the very beginning, these contrasting themes are evident. Matona, mia cara begins with all four voices in an F Major chord and in a fast tempo. The song develops with a mostly homophonic texture and a very marked rhythm, especially in the “Don, don, don” section. 

Ah, Dolente partita opens with only two voices in unison, singing a long, high E. The two voices stay in unison until bar 4 when they drift apart. As a result, it sounds very sorrowful and enigmatic. As the other voices enter, they do so timidly and not simultaneously. Only in bar 15 do all five voices sing together. However, just after that, in bar 16, the top two voices become silent. This creates a variety of aural experiences that convey the theme of lamentation.

Monteverdi’s madrigal has a more polyphonic texture than Lasso’s. Consequently, Ah, Dolente partita has a richer sound ambience, but Matona, mia cara has a stronger rhythmic mark. 

As a final contrast, I would like to mention the melodic shape. In Lasso’s madrigal, there are some upward and downward lines, with a lot of repetition of the melody, so it could be sung in a group with a dance-like feeling. Monteverdi’s melody, however, tends to move downward or remain flat, which is most evident towards the end, as if the music is taking small steps toward death.

References

Arnold, Denis Midgley. “Claudio Monteverdi”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 28 Mar. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Claudio-Monteverdi. Accessed 16 September 2022.

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. “Orlando di Lasso”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 10 Jun. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Orlando-di-Lasso. Accessed 16 September 2022.

MORTENSEN, B., 2009. Recording Reviews – [Claudio Monteverdi: Madrigals]: “Flaming Heart”; “Fire and Ashes”. Choral Journal, 50(5), pp. 60-61. Accessed 16 September 2022.

item.title: Listening to Oscar Peterson – Hymn To Freedom
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points…
item.content:encoded:
I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points out that when you think about jazz names, Petterson’s is not the first that comes to your mind (Johnson, 2022).

Until today, I was unaware of Oscar Peterson’s name or work. Therefore, I decided to listen to “Hymn To Freedom”, a song featured in the article.

Oscar Peterson was born in Montreal, Canada on August 15, 1925 and grew up in a family where music was required of all five children. At the age of seven, he was able to play trumpet and piano. In his teens, he was already a prodigy when he became the star attraction of Canada’s renowned big band, the Johnny Holmes Orchestra (Peterson, 2003), and he was just 20 years old when he made his first trio recordings for RCA.

As a result of his musical genius, he was able to play with and alongside many jazz legends of the era, including Ella Fitzgerald, Roy Eldridge, Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker, and Billie Holiday (Johnson, 2022).

From 1959-1965, he formed and played with the Oscar Peterson trio with Ray Brown on bass and Ed Thigpen on drums, becoming one of jazz history’s most celebrated groups. Jazz historian Alyn Shipton explains one of their strengths as “Peterson’s skill at promoting group interaction marked the beginning of a seismic shift in piano trios.” (Hansen, 2014).

During the 1960s, there was racial segregation throughout the United States and Canada, and Peterson suffered a lot of racism when he toured with the Oscar Peterson trio. However, the experience of touring all over the world and especially his experiences in the south of the United States and observing the approach Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took to peaceful protest, led him to write his most influential work, the “Hymn to Freedom” (Small, 2021).

People all over the world quickly embraced “Hymn To Freedom” as the anthem of the Civil Rights Movement when it was written in 1962. A timeless and relevant piece, this song has been played at many major events around the globe.

This song’s main melody captured my attention from the first listen. The song reminded me of a gospel song infused with blues and jazz. 

In terms of structure, Peterson plays the melody four times before going into his solo, then returning to the original melody one last time. I believe this is an effective way of structuring a hymn, since the first four times he repeats the melody with almost no variation. As a result, the listener is able to engage with the melodic intention of the song. The piano solo builds upon the previous chord progression, but it is melodically much more unique than those first four repetitions, creating some interest. He concludes the solo with an apotheosis, but then the original melody is played softer, calmer, bringing peace to the listener’s heart.

My favorite part of this melody is the contrary motion technique, in which both voices go in opposite directions. While I’m still trying to figure out why I find it so pleasing to hear, I think it’s because it constantly creates a broader range of sounds. This makes it bigger and more interesting as a way of moving to the next part.

References

Johnson, M., 2022. DID JAZZ FORGET ABOUT OSCAR PETERSON?. [online] Mic.Com. Available at: https://www.mic.com/culture/oscar-peterson-black-white [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Hansen, F.A., 2014, The arrangement qualities and musical style of the Oscar Peterson Trio: 1959–1965, Five Towns College [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Peterson, O., 2003, “A Jazz Odyssey: The Life of Oscar Peterson”, Jazz Education Journal, vol. 35, no. 4, pp. C2-C4, C7 [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Small, C., 2021. The Black + White Truth about Oscar Peterson and racism in Canada. POV Magazine. Available at: https://povmagazine.com/the-black-white-truth-about-oscar-peterson-and-racism-in-canada/ [Accessed September 15, 2022].

item.content:encoded:
I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to make some research about the composer.

A Prince who composed secular madrigals, sacred vocal music, and instrumental music, Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa (c 1566 – 1613) published six books of madrigals and three books of sacred pieces during his lifetime. He was also notorious for brutally murdering his wife and lover in bed. In addition to this cold-hearted murder, many depraved tales have been told about Gesualdo’s mental health. Through these stories (whether true or not, it’s up for debate), we can trace a psychological portrait behind the composer whose work represents the culmination of Renaissance music at the end of the 16th century.

His harmonic language is still considered daring and extravagant today because it incorporates elements of the late Italian madrigals, characterized by sound experimentalism. He used complex chromaticism in a way that was extraordinary for his time. This would not be heard again, or even hinted at until Wagner, Schoenberg and Stravinsky took it to new heights.

This idiosyncratic use of chromaticism was not only an attempt to break the rules, representing his era in which Mannerism was emerging as deliberately disruptive but also had a rather specific objective: word painting.

As an example, when the subject of Amor, pace non chero of his 1st Book of Madrigals calls for his lover, he uses consonance and long notes (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

But in Mille volte il moro of his 6th Book of Madrigals, the Morte (death) is described with uncontrolled polyphony and highly dissonant intervals (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

It’s interesting to see how the technical complexity and themes changed from one book to another during his short life. The polyphonic tradition of the Renaissance dominates the first two books, while harmonic experimentalism dominates the third and fourth books. The last two, however, are characterized by more chromatic and dissonant writing, typically associated with mature composers. Considering the themes, his first two books are more simplistic, whereas his last two books are more dramatic in depicting themes of torture, pain, sadness, and death.

It surprised me to find that although we see Gesualdo as an avant-garde musical genius of his time, some people consider him conservative.

“As conservative as it was possible to be in this time. Monteverdi was the radical, the new. There is a very curious letter from the poet Guarini, in which he says he prefers Gesualdo to the modern style because he is ‘so far from the hardness of Monteverdi.’ For Guarini, Gesualdo is so nice, so easy! Exactly the opposite of what we now think.”

(Ross, 2011)

Even though other contemporary composers experimented with new sonorities and pushed further the boundaries of what music could be, I believe Gesualdo was one of the leading composers of the late Renaissance. While developing polyphony, a better sense of structure and rhythmic order, he explored contrasting emotions (like in Dolcissima mia vita) and influenced composers hundreds of years after his death.

References

Ross, A., 2011. Gesualdo. Alex Ross: The Rest Is Noise. Available at: https://www.therestisnoise.com/2011/12/gesualdo.html [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Burton-Hill, C., 2014. Gesualdo: Glorious music and grisly murder. BBC Culture. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20130905-a-16th-century-musical-badass [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Garbuio, R.L. & Fiorini, C.F., 2015. “amor” e “morte” Nos Madrigais de Carlo Gesualdo: Um estudo sobre o desenvolvimento da escrita musical e textual. Per Musi. Available at: https://www.scielo.br/j/pm/a/rfCGr7VrcVTbmsczxX8YTsn/ [Accessed September 14, 2022].
